QuestionContent.Title: Section 1: Little Knowledge - Q1.1
QuestionContent.Text: This section tests your understanding of basic ontology components and the ability to recognise them in graphical and textual representations. Consider the model, represented in Warren formalism and answer the following question. Identify the main model components from the model
QuestionContent.FormattedContent:
Warren
PersonTypeA has, amongst other things, at least one daughter, at least one son, and also no other than dog pets.

How many named classes can you identify from the model?

QuestionContent.Title: Section 1: Little Knowledge - Q1.2
QuestionContent.Text: This section tests your understanding of basic ontology components and the ability to recognise them in graphical and textual representations. Consider the model, represented in Warren formalism and answer the following question. Identify the main model components from the model.
QuestionContent.FormattedContent:
Warren
PersonTypeA has, amongst other things, at least one daughter, at least one son, and also no other than dog pets.

How many relations can you identify from the model?

QuestionContent.Title: Section 1: Little Knowledge - Q2.1
QuestionContent.Text: This section tests your understanding of basic ontology components and the ability to recognise them in graphical and textual representations. Consider the model, represented in Warren formalism and answer the following question. Identifying the different quantifiers from the model.
QuestionContent.FormattedContent:
Warren
PersonTypeA has, amongst other things, at least one daughter, at least one son, and also no other than dog pets.

How many universal restrictions (owl:allValuesFrom) can you identify in the model?

QuestionContent.Title: Section 1: Little Knowledge - Q2.2
QuestionContent.Text: This section tests your understanding of basic ontology components and the ability to recognise them in graphical and textual representations. Consider the model, represented in Warren formalism and answer the following question. Identifying the different quantifiers from the model.
QuestionContent.FormattedContent:
Warren
PersonTypeA has, amongst other things, at least one daughter, at least one son, and also no other than dog pets.

How many existential restrictions (owl:someValuesFrom) can you identify in the model?

QuestionContent.Title: Section 2: Some Knowledge - Q3
QuestionContent.Text: This section tests your understanding of the implications of ontology axioms and restrictions. Consider the model, represented in Warren formalism and answer question 3 below.
QuestionContent.FormattedContent:
Warren
PetLoverTypeA has, amongst other things, no other than Dog pets.

Select the statement that describes instances of PetLoverTypeA correctly.

Selection.Text: Instances of PetLoverTypeA must have a Dog pet and cannot have other types of pets.
Instances of PetLoverTypeA might not have a Dog pet and cannot have other types of pets.
Instances of PetLoverTypeA must have a Dog pet and can also have other types of pets.
Instances of PetLoverTypeA might not have a Dog pet and can also have other types of pets.

QuestionContent.Title: Section 2: Some Knowledge - Q4
QuestionContent.Text: This section tests your understanding of the implications of ontology axioms and restrictions. Consider the model, represented in Warren formalism and answer question 4 below.
QuestionContent.FormattedContent:
Warren
PetLoverTypeB has, amongst other things, at least one Cat pet.

Select the statement that describes instances of PetLoverTypeB correctly.

Selection.Text: Instances of PetLoverTypeB must have a Cat pet and cannot have other types of pets.
Instances of PetLoverTypeB might not have a Cat pet and cannot have other types of pets.
Instances of PetLoverTypeB must have a Cat pet and can also have other types of pets.
Instances of PetLoverTypeB might not have a Cat pet and can also have other types of pets.

QuestionContent.Title: Section 2: Some Knowledge - Q5
QuestionContent.Text: This section tests your understanding of the implications of ontology axioms and restrictions. Consider the model, represented in Warren formalism and answer question 5 below.
QuestionContent.FormattedContent:
Warren
PetLoverTypeC has, amongst other things, no other than Cat pets and no other than Dog pets. There are no individuals that can be both of type Dog and type Cat.

Select the statement that correctly represents instances of PetLoverTypeC.

Selection.Text: Instances of PetLoverTypeC must have 2 pets - a Dog and a Cat.
Instances of PetLoverTypeC might have 2 pets - a Dog and a Cat but also might not have any pets.
Instances of PetLoverTypeC cannot have any pets.
Instances of PetLoverTypeC could have 0 to n pets from type Cat or 0 to n pets from type Dog but not both.

QuestionContent.Title: Section 3: Expert Knowledge - Q6
QuestionContent.Text: This section tests your ability to reason with ontology models, as well as compare and relate them to each other. Consider models A and B both describing PetLoverTypeE, each represented in Warren formalism and answer question 6 below.
QuestionContent.FormattedContent:
Model A: PetLoverTypeE Model B: PetLoverTypeE
PetLoverTypeE has, amongst other things, at least one Cat pet and at least one Dog pet and also no other than Cat and Dog pets. PetLoverTypeE has, amongst other things, at least one Cat pet and at least one Dog pet.

Select the correct statement about models A and B describing PetLoverTypeE.

Selection.Text: Model A allows for instances of PetLoverTypeE to have a pet that is neither a Dog nor a Cat.
Model B allows for instances of PetLoverTypeE to have a pet that is neither a Dog nor a Cat.
None of the models allow for instances of PetLoverTypeE to have a pet that is neither a Dog nor a Cat.
Both models allow for instances of PetLoverTypeE to have a pet that is neither a Dog nor a Cat.

QuestionContent.Title: Section 3: Expert Knowledge - Q7
QuestionContent.Text: This section tests your ability to reason with ontology models, as well as compare and relate them to each other. Consider models A and B describing PetLoverTypeD and PerLoverTypeF, each represented in Warren formalism and answer question 7 below.
QuestionContent.FormattedContent:
Model A: PetLoverTypeD Model B: PetLoverTypeF
PetLoverTypeD has, amongst other things, at least one pet that is not a Dog. PetLoverTypeF has, amongst other things, no other than Dog pets.

Is it true that PetLoverTypeD is disjoint to PetLoverTypeF? That is, there can be no instance that is at the same time of type PetLoverTypeD and PetLoverTypeF.

Selection.Text: Yes
No

QuestionContent.Title: Section 3: Expert Knowledge - Q8
QuestionContent.Text: This section tests your ability to reason with ontology models, as well as compare and relate them to each other. Consider models A and B describing PetLoverTypeG and PerLoverTypeF, each represented in Warren formalism and answer question 8 below.
QuestionContent.FormattedContent:
Model A: PetLoverTypeG Model B: PetLoverTypeF
PetLoverTypeG has, amongst other things, pets that are no other than not Dogs. PetLoverTypeF has, amongst other things, no other than Dog pets.

Is it true that PetLoverTypeG is disjoint to PetLoverTypeF? That is, there can be no instance that is at the same time of type PetLoverTypeG and PetLoverTypeF.

Selection.Text: Yes
No

QuestionContent.Title: Section 3: Expert Knowledge - Q9
QuestionContent.Text: This section tests your ability to reason with ontology models, as well as compare and relate them to each other. Consider models A and B describing PetLoverTypeD and PerLoverTypeH, each represented in Warren formalism and answer question 9 below.
QuestionContent.FormattedContent:
Model A: PetLoverTypeD Model B: PetLoverTypeH
PetLoverTypeD has, amongst other things, at least one pet that is not a Dog. PetLoverTypeH has, amongst other things, at least one Dog pet.

Is it true that PetLoverTypeD is disjoint to PetLoverTypeH? That is, there can be no instance that is at the same time of type PetLoverTypeD and PetLoverTypeH.

Selection.Text: Yes
No
